title: The Separate Disscussion
body:
A quote from Riot Shadow

> [{quoted}](name=Riot ShadowStorm,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=Ql5gi7Ah,comment-id=0000000600040000,timestamp=2015-05-17T02:24:38.177+0000)
>
> Right, I should clarify - I'm only trying to point out the fact that those pieces exist. Whether they're good enough is a separate discussion entirely. It just feels really premature to me to say that Ekko's lore is lacking, and to get really angry about it, when we haven't even released him yet.

Ok, here is that separate discussion. Those pieces that exsist are far from good enough in my opionion.

Sneak Dog pointed it out pretty clearly

> [{quoted}](name=Sneak Dog,realm=EUW,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=Ql5gi7Ah,comment-id=000000060004,timestamp=2015-05-17T00:52:41.203+0000)
>
> The Shurima event storyline was boring and had a very boring medium. Arisen was great but not really officially released, just put on the forums.
> Kalistas invocation/pledge told nothing more than the short summary.
> Scourge of the Desert was about Shurima and Noxus.
> Mountain wasn't much really, given that we have no context to put it in.
> The feats of Braum is a nice piece of character building.
> 
> I'm not blaming people for assuming this is basically all the lore we're gonna get for Ekko, only Azir and Sion really had more lore than their short bio. Perhaps we'll get it twice or thrice like with Kalista.
> 
> (Well, there's also Xeraths modus operandi and main motivation getting changed when Azirs story got released, which isn't helping things much from my perspective. On top of that, the first post-retcon event, Freljord, being all build-up and no conclusion where Trundle got removed and replaced.)
> 
> I'm pessimistic about Riots lore and I do believe I have solid reasoning. I'm not going to be excited about upcoming lore. You'll probably just tell us the same shallow character, and (more importantly for me personally) perhaps taking another old champion and changing/replacing it to fit in the new characters lore.
> 
> ***
> 
> Regardless of it all, it's fair to wait for his official release before judging once again.

replies.body:
Cool, I'm happy to kick this off. First, here are the stories I was referencing in that post:

{{champion:268}} : [Arisen](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/story-art/zmvrQ7I6-short-stories-azirarisen) | [Shurima Event Storyline](http://promo.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/shurima/story/index.html)
{{champion:429}} : [Invocation](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/story-art/UTTHinkA-short-stories-kalista-invocation) | [The Pledge](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GnT8jVCyh_E)
{{champion:421}} : [Scourge of the Desert](http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/creative-spotlight/reksai-scourge-desert)
{{champion:432}} : [Mountain](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CX8iSobsKTY)

Specifically, these champions did NOT get long in-client bios, but had these stories released alongside the champion's official release (which I'm defining as when we activated them on Live servers). I'll refer to these as **launch stories**.

To give an idea of how I personally think about these: I consider Mountain to be a story about Bard, presented in video form. It tells a story about how he interacts with the world. How successful it is as a launch story is the "separate conversation" I'm hoping to have here. Mirage Night, TerraRising, Sneak Dog, and others have all claimed that these launch stories are not good enough. I want to better understand why you all feel that way.

I'm going to assume that short in-client bios are here to stay; but I agree that we need to do a better job making all pieces of a Champion's lore available in one place. For the sake of argument, let's say we put a link in the client for each champion, that brings up ALL of their lore (and heck, links to related champions' lore as well) in one page.

*(DISCLAIMER: I don't know what our plans are around in-client lore. I'm just using the above as an example to frame discussion around the stories themselves)*

So, with that assumption made, here are some things I'm curious about:

* What parts did you like about the launch stories? What parts didn't work for you?
* Does the medium matter to you? Are there different mediums that we should explore?
* What do you think the goal of launch stories should be? How do you define a successful launch story?
* How much does world-building matter to you in regards to launch stories? Specifically thinking Rek'Sai here, or even [Sion's Reborn piece](http://promo.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/reborn/) which focused a lot more on the world around the Champion.
* Is there other information we should share about champions at launch, in addition to the launch stories?

Feel free to answer some, all, or even give other thoughts not covered here. I'm heading out for a while; I'll jump back in either later tonight, or sometime tomorrow. But don't wait on me... respond to each other, try to elaborate, clarify, or even challenge (nicely!) each others' views.

And lastly, quick reminder that everything I say here is my own opinion as a player, I can't promise anything... the usual caveats.

The problem, for me at least, is that the change to short (and I mean SHORT) in-client bios felt like the lore was being destroyed, not rewritten.

Look at Skarner. I will admit he is a more extreme case, but he illustrates my point quite well. Here's his old lore:

> Centuries ago, there lived a race of creatures as ferocious as they were wise. The brackern were unusual beings blessed with the earth's primal magic, embodied in the form of crystals. Their kind knew of an arcane ritual to bind their life's essence to a crystal, communing with the magic embedded in it. With this power, the brackern thrived in the Odyn Valley, protecting both creatures and crystals alike. Despite attacks from those looking to claim the primal magic, it seemed that nothing could get past the brackern's defenses. Nothing, that is, until the devastation of a Rune War. 
>
A vicious battle was fought near the Odyn Valley and the unleashed chaotic magic poisoned the crystals. The brackern began to grow sick and die, and no amount of defensive magic could reverse the effects. To avoid extinction, their only course was to hibernate underground until the wars stopped. The strongest, most intelligent brackern hibernated closer to the surface to awaken first and assess the world's condition for the return of their race. The recent mining operations and violent escalation in Kalamanda were enough to awaken the first of these vanguards. When Skarner burst to the surface, he lashed out in anger and confusion. Reason eventually won out over his anger when he realized that the agents of the League who found him were simply functionaries. Skarner was invited to the Institute of War to share the brackern's story. In return, the summoners told him about the history that his kind had slept through. Much had been done to curb the unchecked use of magic since the Rune Wars, but it was obvious that the world was not yet safe for his kind to reawaken. For now, however, there is a place where Skarner can use his power to change the world into one to which his kind could eventually return: the League of Legends. 
>
>
"The humans have not yet learned to control their magic - what once was Kalamanda is now a crystal scar on the history of this world."
>
â€• Skarner

Here's his new lore:

>Skarner, the crystalline guardian, defends the entrance to a realm deep beneath the shuriman wastes. The few who survive trespassing his domain describe a creature of terrifying intelligence, anger, and precision. What this merciless creature protects, no one knows.

Do you see what I mean? There's _nothing_ left. Before, he was the first of his kind to reawaken, trying to make the world safe for more to resurface. The lore team complained about not being able to tell stories before the retcon. Well, here's one: What is Skarner DOING to help his species? We will never know, because as of the Shurima event, he now mysteriously guards mysterious things for mysterious reasons while being mysterious. In Shurima. What stories can you tell about that? There is less than what you started with, but he couldn't stay the same because Kalamanda is no longer canon, despite it being one of the only real stories the lore team _ever bothered to tell._ We don't have new opportunities. We have a few sentences that explain the bare minimum needed to tell us what the champion is. Not who, what. We don't know anything ABOUT Skarner anymore. He just guards a thing.

Specifically referring to those four stories...

A) Azir's stories are fine, but they raise questions, not answers. How did Azir get resurrected by Sivir's blood? She's related to him and magic is involved somehow, but how can Sivir be related to Azir when Azir's entire family died? There are any number of explanations, but we have absolutely nothing to go on, so there's no point in speculating. I remember a Rioter getting annoyed that we were asking for answers about that, instead of just speculating to ourselves, but we don't have any hints as to what happened, so what are we supposed to speculate on? There's also the fact that almost all of Riot's recent lore releases have been about new things, with the exception of Amumu's little video. They raise questions about a champion, but since we have no guarantee Riot'll ever get around to answering them, we don't really care.

B) Kalista is a spirit of vengeance. Offer yourself to her and she will get back at someone who wronged you.

...That is all we have to go on. A video, a short bio, and a long story, and they all say the same thing. Again, this is a problem of raising questions that are not getting answered. It's like instead of including a short bio for people who don't care and a longer story for people who do care, Riot just decided to make the short bio and the long bio the same thing, just one has more words in it. Invocation is more about the sword-wife that Kalista pacts with than Kalista herself.

C) This is good, primarily because this is a champion that Riot's primary long story concept works on. This also happened to Kalista and Amumu's longer lore, and to a lesser extent Gnar's, but Riot's been fond of having some normal denizen of Runeterra (or Rengar, in Gnar's case) react to the champion, to make them look larger than life, and make them truly worthy of being called a 'champion'. The problem is that these stories are actually about the point of view character; we empathize more with the narrator than the champion. This works for Rek'Sai because she's less of a character and more of a hazard, but none of the other three have anything explained about them. This shows us that their origins are shrouded in mystery to the average denizen of Runeterra, but we're not the average denizen of Runeterra, especially now that summoners are not a thing. We should not be guessing about every single champion that has been released since the retcon; it gets boring. It's like a series of murder mysteries that never explains the murderer; it just skips from one to another and you're still wondering 'Did the Butler from the first case do it?'

D) Bard's entire thing is being cryptic, which wouldn't be a problem if, again, I didn't think that narrative will never get back to him and therefore speculation is pointless. I learned more from having Rioters explain the video than actually watching the video. It's nice, but it's not something I can get my teeth into and analyze, you know?

And as for Echo...that short form lore is the worst I've seen since Rammus'. It's just  badly written (it sounds like a elementary schooler doing a book report; it's just a listing of his most sapient features, with no rhyme or reason to placement.) I'm going to rewrite it right now:

A prodigy from the rough streets of Zaun, Ekko uses his invention, the Zero-Drive, to explore the branching possibilities of reality and twist any situation to his advantage. Whenever he's not experimenting with multi-dimensional probability, he can be found running wild with the other lost children of Zaun. He revels in this freedom, and whenever something tries to threaten his friends, he's willing to endure anything to defend them.'

Same basic words, just put together in a way that the sentences actually flow. (I removed the last sentence because it just felt like a tagline to an action figure, which is kinda what lore is reading as to me recently.)

The video, meanwhile, falls under the same thing that the Azir video does; it raises more questions than it answers. The only things it states are Ekko's abilities and his basic philosophy. It doesn't explain who the memorial is for, who he's fighting against, why he's fighting against him, etc. It just raises a bunch of questions that narrative will fail to answer.

Honestly, I don't have many problems with the launch stories themselves. But I want things other than launch stories; I want actual character development, not just character establishment. All Narrative seems to exist for is to write little story blurbs and cool advertisements for new stuff.

> [{quoted}](name=Hellioning,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=0lfN1fln,comment-id=00000003,timestamp=2015-05-17T05:39:25.168+0000)
>
> C) This is good, primarily because this is a champion that Riot's primary long story concept works on. This also happened to Kalista and Amumu's longer lore, and to a lesser extent Gnar's, but Riot's been fond of having some normal denizen of Runeterra (or Rengar, in Gnar's case) react to the champion, to make them look larger than life, and make them truly worthy of being called a 'champion'. The problem is that these stories are actually about the point of view character; we empathize more with the narrator than the champion. This works for Rek'Sai because she's less of a character and more of a hazard, but none of the other three have anything explained about them. This shows us that their origins are shrouded in mystery to the average denizen of Runeterra, but we're not the average denizen of Runeterra, especially now that summoners are not a thing. We should not be guessing about every single champion that has been released since the retcon; it gets boring. It's like a series of murder mysteries that never explains the murderer; it just skips from one to another and you're still wondering 'Did the Butler from the first case do it?'


Well, there's another big reason for this.

When they murdered the League itself, you had a bunch of people excited because it meant "Riot can kill Champions and end their stories now without worrying about still playing them in-game!"

But I can tell you right now - it's not going to happen.   Or if it does, it will be done comic-book style, in that a Champ will be killed before a rework in lore and then brought back.

We get to experience lore from Mr. Nobody's point of view because the Lore writer swore that lore without the League can have lasting consequences.

You can't reconcile eternally milking a character with the possibility of irrevocably changing them.

So instead - we have to see the new lore from the point of view of nameless Runeterran goons we don't care about.  Why?  Because they're not being sold, so Riot can put them in peril, and have their "lasting consequences" they touted so much when they killed the League.

But I don't care what happens to "Noxian Helmet Bro Number 3" or "Shuriman Dude Who Got Fondled By Amumu".  I. Just. Don't. Care.  And I don't think most of the fandom and player base does, either.   

You don't read the X-men comics to hear about the life of a pizza delivery boy who was once saved by a stray Sentinel blast by Colossus and then went home and went about his day, never once looking back at that superhero fight.

You seem to mostly have issues with Riot keeping secrets.

I think that some of the secrets they keep are only really meaningful if they are secret.  Take Kalista for example:
You can tell she is a spooky specter with scary secrets.  I think her character would suffer if we knew _exactly_ why she is the way she is.  As is, we can infer that she is Shadow Isle's (duh) and that something serious must have happened to her to make her the way she is.  This something is likely a very strong form of betrayal and is probably not something she has gotten even for, since vengeance spirits tend to go away after they do that.  She is in the Mordekaiser/Hecarim range of undeath, which means she is kind of a big deal and is one of the older undead, possibly from the Shadow Isle's transformation time.  After that it is more or less pure speculation, but we have a strong idea about her story and character without the specifics.

I think that most of the questions around the less mysterious champs (like Azir) should have the information around to make those questions answerable if we really think about it (and we should probably be able to get multiple answers reasonably).  For the more mysterious champs that are about the past (like Kalista), answers should be more speculative but information around their mysteries should be available in the same way that the less mysterious champs questions's answers are.

That's the thing; if we're never going to get the answers to something, why bother asking questions? We can get close, but unless Riot just drops anvil sized hints that basically confirm something anyway, constant speculation just makes me tired.

Why do you want the straight out answers to something?  If you are told the answers you just know.  There is nothing that can be done with that knowledge, it just sits there.

I don't want those straight out answers because that makes lore boring and stale.  If we knew the story of the Shadow Isles, for example, what more would there be?  Why would they ever make another champ from there?  The story would already have been told.  The Shadow Isles would be left behind to stagnate forever.

Without questions the lore has nothing to do.  The lore would be over.

But if they are never going to answer the questions, why bother asking the questions? If I'm never gonna be told the story of the shadow isles I have no reason to try and figure it out because I'm never gonna know if I'm right or not.

There's a reason that at the end of every mystery they tell you who the murderer was; if they didn't, you'd find it unsatisfying.

Why do you not want to figure out how you think the story goes?  If you can get it so you can say within reasonable doubt that what you think is correct, shouldn't that be enough to give you satisfaction?  I don't see why you need Riot to tell you whether you are right or not if you can show that you have a good answer.

No, actually. Randomly guessing based on a limited amount of information does not entertain me at all. I like mysteries, yes, but I like fair mysteries. I want to be able to solve the mystery alongside the detective, instead of getting the set up and all of the clues and then the book just going on to the next story.

I honestly do not understand where you are coming from here. What's the point in speculating over something that is never gonna be answered?

Random guessing is not what I am saying you do.  I said you speculate, you take what information you have and you use that to try and come up with the most supported answer you can for the question you have.  You don't just say "I bet Jinx killed Quinn's brother", you say "I bet Jinx killed Quinn's brother, and the reason I think that is ___ and ___".  Then someone else says "I disagree because ___ and ___", and then you debate it until you have fully developed each other's point of view and can see what the full evidence for and against your point of view is.  Then you look at this evidence and say "Ok, I guess Jinx killing Quinn's brother doesn't make sense" or "I can see why you disagree, but I think the evidence really leans towards Jinx killing Quinn's brother".

The point is speculating and trying to develop the best answer you can.

What is the point of just having everything told to you?  There is nothing to say about it, it just is.  You just get to say "Oh man, I loved when Lucian launched that assault on Karma's temple" or "I really think that Zac is just kind of a jerk".

But they don't give us enough information to speculate on. For example, we know that Sivir is related to Azir, even though Azir's entire family was supposedly exploded by the ascension ritual gone wrong. There's a bunch of possible explanations for this; Azir could have a family member outside the city, or maybe the ascension ritual didn't kill them and just teleported them somewhere, or maybe everything related to Azir's backstory is wrong and it'll be revealed that Azir is just Sivir's dad in a bird mask.

We can't argue over whether these things happened or not because we don't have enough information to say one way or another. We don't have any mention of Azir having family outside the capital, or of Sivir complaining that her dad is crazy, or anything. 

We simply don't have any thing to speculate on, so there's no point in speculating.

Actually, it should be pretty simple to have an idea as to how Sivir is related to Azir.  I mean really, yes all of Azir's family is killed in the blast.  His wife, his daughter, his son.  It would be ridiculous to assume the lore was just lying, that would make all lore worthless because they could just be lies.

Is it really not that hard to have a plausible answer for how Sivir is a direct descendant of Azir within the confines of what we have been told.

That's the exact opposite of what I am saying. I apologize if I'm unclear.

But there are MANY explanations as to how Sivir is related to Azir despite his family supposedly dying. Maybe they didn't actually die, maybe he had relatives outside the city, whatever. The point is we don't have any proof one way or another, so speculation is completely pointless.
Apologies if this is an ignorant question, but can you explain why it's important to you to know exactly how Sivir is related to Azir? What does that add that you find missing currently?

> [{quoted}](name=Riot ShadowStorm,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=0lfN1fln,comment-id=0000000300000001000000000000000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2015-05-18T02:24:46.208+0000)
>
> Apologies if this is an ignorant question, but can you explain why it's important to you to know exactly how Sivir is related to Azir? What does that add that you find missing currently?

To be honest, adding Azir into the game, and magically making Sivir related to him first draws my reaction of ''Ok?'' rather than ''I've been waiting FOREVER to know this!'' Why? Well because, Sivir was kind of already established as a character. No one really had questions about her, unlike the Ekko x Jinx x Vi x Caitlyn x C fiasco, like most people mentioned in here. She was known as a wealthy mercenary, and that's really all we ever knew. 

Here, I will now commence creating a terrible short description (sort of a general example) on how revealing Sivir being related to Azir would have been a secret that you have revealed.

Sivir was a child of prophecy, meant to save her village of the Noxian invasions. By learning the truth of her ancestor once deemed a ruler, she will rescue her people. She has come to the league in hopes of learning the secrets affiliated with her mysterious ancestor. 

See, now revealing Azir being related to Sivir would have been more of a reveal instead of a simple ''Oh okay, well that's new'' sort of thing.

Now, the reason on why Sivir's relations to Azir would be important to some people, is because Riot has never mentioned any connection to Sivir having some god ancestor. 

No one ever really speculated on Sivir being related to Azir.

To put it into better terms, imagine you were a LoL lore fan not working with Riot, and another fan just like you, out of the blue tells you Sivir is related to Azir. 

What would be your first reaction? Mine would be, ''where is your proof'', AKA ''how is Sivir related to Azir?''

So I see the question brought up of Sivir's relations with Azir more of a reaction to something new rather than a question lore fans are asking.

Hope I answered your question.

Kalisa's lore is ironically probably the easiest of the most recent releases to piece together if you know the story of the Shadow Isles and just buy Blade of the Ruined King on her.  That's the kind of subtle storytelling but with CONCRETE answers IN-GAME if you look hard enough that shows that there is a story there, rather than bad writing hiding behind the blank wall of "She has a MYSTERIOUS PAAAAST!  WooOooo!"

We do get the idea that she was there and involved, but we really don't know what her role in the events were.  Which I think is great, as that way we get to discuss what it might have been.

Also, we don't really know the story of the Shadow Isles, do we?

> [{quoted}](name=Baron of Bread,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=0lfN1fln,comment-id=00000003000000000000,timestamp=2015-05-17T09:27:26.215+0000)
>
> We do get the idea that she was there and involved, but we really don't know what her role in the events were.  Which I think is great, as that way we get to discuss what it might have been.
> 
> Also, we don't really know the story of the Shadow Isles, do we?

Actually, we do - they squirreled it away in, of all places, Maokai's updated lore.   I know - took me completely by surprise. 

The only things we don't know is what role Mordekaiser and Hecarim played in the story - but we know most of the Lord and Lady's story, Maokai's story, and can infer Kalista's story.  Not incredible details, but two paragraphs of backstory is more than most big past events get lately.

The whole situation is best served by a quote I once saw from a member of the lore team:

"We're not going to just TELL you every Champion's most important secrets."

My response is this - if an author doesn't tell you, you never know.

Hiding all lore behind a wall of "She/He/It has a MYSTERIOUS PAST!" and then claiming that there IS lore - but us inferior mortal players are not allowed to gaze our unworthy eyes upon it means that **there really IS no lore **as far as the we consumers are concerned.

>The whole situation is best served by a quote I once saw from a member of the lore team:

>"We're not going to just TELL you every Champion's most important secrets."

>My response is this - if an author doesn't tell you, you never know.

Hmm, I struggle with this argument a bit. I understand the idea that if we don't reveal things, then those things might as well not exist as far as players know... but should we really be revealing these things right off the bat? Why isn't it acceptable to reveal them over time?

I can't help but think: is Harry Potter a better series if J.K. Rowling puts an appendix at the end of Chamber of Secrets, explaining that Riddle's diary is Horcrux (and explaining what a Horcrux even is)?

Or, maybe a better example - what if Snape's background was revealed in Sorcerer's Stone? He literally has a dark, mysterious past for the entire series, up until the final chapters. Would it have been better to tell that whole story at the start?

My gut says that revealing that information initially would have made the series much less interesting. Do you feel differently? Or is there just something different about LoL that makes this comparison invalid?

Harry Potter is a story with a beginning, middle, and end. Character arcs are concluded, mysteries revealed, etc. We. DON'T. TRUST. YOU. TO. DO. THIS. You haven't concluded or advanced a single story since the retcon. Before the retcon after the JoJ. We're still waiting on a conclusion to the Frejlord event, if there even is one. We're waiting on more background regarding Jinx and Vi, let alone a conclusion, or Caitlyn and C. 

You don't tell a story like Harry Potter, Game of Thrones, or Lord of the Rings. I don't even know why you're comparing your story to theirs because a book is a different medium than a video game. Let's phrase it like this; you're not Mass Effect. You're not World of WarCraft. You're not Mortal Kombat. You're not even DC or Marvel comics, and they reset their universes every 5 years. You do not have a consistent, reliable media that you're dedicated to improving in order to advance and conclude stories. You only produce new characters that MIGHT have vague connections to existing ones, along with a vague video describing them.

If your stories were anything like the ones I've mentioned, then leaving info out is fine. Some things shouldn't even be solved, at least not for years. You don't have that type of setting, and pretending that you do without putting in the work to make it as such pisses us off.

> [{quoted}](name=Riot ShadowStorm,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=0lfN1fln,comment-id=0000000b0003,timestamp=2015-05-17T18:29:31.911+0000)
> My gut says that revealing that information initially would have made the series much less interesting. Do you feel differently? Or is there just something different about LoL that makes this comparison invalid?

The analogy is invalid.

Stories have a beginning and an end -- League of Legends does not.
Stories have overarching and nuanced character arcs, League does not.

You cannot make the argument that you'll develop characters later when that has never happened in the past. Any and every time a character is retouched upon, it is conceptually changed, not advanced. 

How about the other side of the coin. Death of a Salesman. Does it make the story less enjoyable when you know that Willy Lowman is going to die at the end? Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are Dead, Romeo and Juliet (any Shakespeare, for that matter), Life of Pi. None of these stories suffer from keeping things a secret, because the writers are able to tell a profound and nuanced story that is more than just its ending.

It would be fine if you guys revealed things over time.
The problem is, you literally never have post-retcon.
Not once, ever.
If you can come up with a single example, my argument is invalid.

I feel like Riot just saw that the community voted for Lissandra to win the war and said "Well shit, what do we do now guys?  Should we just rewrite everything?".
Apparently, that's indeed what happened, and now we're dealing with it.
But _we'll never know_, because Riot doesn't reveal anything over time.  Nor do they even speak to their community about lore anymore.
The only thing we lore lovers are seeing right now is that lore means nothing to Riot (Contributes no kind of wealth), so they don't feel the need to pay a team to expand on it.

> [{quoted}](name=Noraver,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=0lfN1fln,comment-id=0000000b00030003,timestamp=2015-05-17T18:49:24.255+0000)
>
> It would be fine if you guys revealed things over time.
> The problem is, you literally never have post-retcon.
> Not once, ever.
> If you can come up with a single example, my argument is invalid.

I'm not actually trying to invalidate anybody's argument in this thread - I just want to understand it better. But one example that jumps to mind is Sivir. During the Shurima event, we learned that she is actually the descendant of Shuriman royalty. To me that's a huge thing for Sivir, and answers the question of "why is this random mercenary a noteworthy character in the world?".

Now, granted - that's only one story piece, wrapped up in a bunch of other stuff (including the release of an entire new character). But does that count as revealing more about a character? Or do you see that differently than I do?

To me, a huge thing about Sivir was that in the process of revealing that one completely arbitrary scrap of information, you dismantled the rest of the information about her.

In both of her original lore pieces, Sivir was a legendary mercenary with a nearly flawless success record and a reputation for nearly perfect strategy. She had strong lore connections to Noxus due to being hired by them a lot, which also gave her connections to Demacia because she likely fought against them whenever Noxians hired her.
